10021.description: We are seeking a Japanese speaker to meet with a senior that speaks Japanese as part of Lenox Hill Neighborhood House's Friendly Visiting Program. Lenox Hill Neighborhood House, in partnership with the NYC Department for the Aging, connects volunteers with homebound older New Yorkers to have in home visits on a regular basis. For volunteers, friendly visiting offers the opportunity to cultivate a lasting friendship, to learn from a senior’s life experiences, and to benefit from the personal satisfaction derived from community service. Friendly visiting leads to the creation of meaningful relationships between older adults and volunteers, promoting intergenerational understanding. For the senior, friendly visiting provides a sense of connection to the outside world, something to look forward to, and a sense of contributing to society through sharing their wisdom, knowledge, talents and stories with you. Tasks: Have weekly social, in-home visits with an older adult you are matched with Provide monthly reports/updates to the Friendly Visiting program coordinator Requirements: Commit to being a Friendly Visitor for a minimum of six months Be comfortable establishing a relationship with an older adult Honest, mature, motivated, patient Ability to maintain confidentiality Willing and able to contact the program coordinator should problems arise Participate in an in-person interview Undergo and pass a background check and provide references Email monthly report of hours to coordinator
10021.title: Japanese Speaking Friendly Visitor Needed

10036.description: We Connect The Dots' (WCTD) Discovery Day highlights the endless career possibilities offered through careers in STEAM (Science, Technology, Engineering, Arts, Math) and also showcases the programs we offer through out the year. What will be expected of me as a volunteer? As a volunteer, you would be expected to help and mentor students by being interactive and supportive during the program when the students need help by having the opportunity to learn how to inspire students to be life-long learners. Some of the examples you may be assigned to do is mentoring students, registration, giving tours of the facility, setting up and cleaning up before and after the program. Do I need any special skills? No, you do not need to have any special skills. Our program incorporates a variety of team building activities that support our goal to engage students to work collaboratively. The result is that by volunteering you will benefit from the experience and come away with valuable skills. To learn more about the opportunity reach out to our team at events@we-connect-the-dots.org, to learn more about the program please visit our website at http://we-connect-the-dots.org/discoveryday2018/ Shifts: (any or all) Monday, April 16th 8:00 am - 3:30 pm Tuesday, April 17th 8:00 am - 3:30 pm Wednesday, April 18th 8:00 am - 3:30 pm
10036.title: Do you enjoy learning along side students?  WCTD's Discovery Day starts the journey.

10036.description: We are hosting a Medicare Scams & Abuse Training for people interested in becoming a Certified Senior Medicare Patrol Instructor! Medicare is a very complex health insurance program, which makes it prone to fraud & scams! This free training will teach: Foundations of Medicare Differences between healthcare Errors, Abuse, & Fraud Common & recent Medicare scams & fraud schemes How to protect yourself & your Medicare Ways to get involved after becoming a Certified Senior Medicare Patrol Instructor! Volunteer Instructors lead workshops on Medicare fraud & Healthcare scams around NYC! For more information, contact Victoria 212-398-6565 ext 235 or vthornton@liveon-ny.org Mission: The New York Senior Medicare Patrol works to empower seniors so that they can protect themselves against healthcare fraud, learn to detect errors on their medical statements and report Medicare abuse when suspected.
10036.title: Medicare Scams & Abuse Training

10036.description: Come join us as we educate children about healthy eating, food, and taste. Training Dates: Monday, February 26th, 5:30 PM Wednesday, February 28th, 12:00 PM What is Spoons Across America? Spoons Across America (SAA) is a not-for-profit organization dedicated to educating children, teachers, and families about the benefits of healthy eating though food and nutrition-based educational programs for children. What is Agriculture Literacy Week? Spoons Across America is the primary New York City implementer of Cornell Cooperative Extension’s New York Agriculture Literacy Week. In this free program for New York City schools, 1st and 2nd graders learn about New York state agriculture - what kinds of food are grown and produced in the state, and the people who are involved in growing and producing them. Spoons Across America trains volunteers to read a selected storybook and lead a related curriculum activity. Between March 12 and April 25, 2018, volunteers will read Before We Eat: From Farm to Table by Pat Brisson. Students will be taken on the journey from farm to table to understand different aspects of agriculture and the many possible careers involved. This is a captivating glimpse of what it takes to bring the food we eat to us in order to nourish our bodies and spirits. What do Volunteers do? After participating in a hands-on training, volunteers participate in and lead all aspects of Agriculture Literacy Week implementation. Volunteer responsibilities include reading the Agriculture Literacy Week book aloud to the class, leading an activity related to the book, and set up and clean up. We are looking for individuals enthusiastic about healthy eating and children’s programming to join us! Volunteer Training: All volunteers receive training at the Spoons Across America offices (630 Ninth Avenue @ 44th Street in Manhattan), and are required to attend one of the following training dates: Monday, February 26th, 5:30 PM Wednesday, February 28th, 12:00 PM **** Do you work for a business or company that wants to make a volunteer commitment? We can schedule a special training session for groups of 10 or more people, onsite or at our offices. Contact Ali for more information. When do your programs take place? Agriculture Literacy Week programs occur DURING SCHOOL HOURS. Please be advised that there are no after-work hours available for Agriculture Literacy Week. I'm ready to go! How do I sign up? If you are interested in volunteering with Spoons Across America this year, please contact Ali McDowell, Director of Programs and Partnerships, at ali@spoonsacrossamerica.org. In your email, please indicate which training session you will attend: Monday, February 26th at 5:30 PM or Wednesday, February 28th at 12:00 PM. * Please note: Volunteers must complete a background check prior to the program date.
10036.title: New York Agriculture Literacy Week - join us in the classroom!
10036.org: From Farm to Table d/b/a Spoons Across America

10036.description: Are you looking for a volunteer opportunity? Interested in volunteering your time to a worth cause while doing something you enjoy? If so, the American Liver Foundation's Greater New York Division is looking for a DJ or live band to volunteer on Sunday, June 3rd to perform at our Annual Liver Life Walk New York City. https://liverlifewalk.org/newyorkcity/ Date: Sunday, June 3, 2018 Location: Pier 84 | Hudson River Park 555 12th Ave, New York, NY 10036 Time Frame: 8:00 AM - 1:00 PM Expectations: Be able to arrive at Pier 84 by 8:00 AM and stay until 1:00 PM Not shy to make announcements on the mic Must be able to provide own equipment (sound system, mic, etc.) We are looking for a variety of family friendly music to keep our walkers engaged and excited. Due to the fact that this is a fundraiser, we are looking for someone who would be willing to donate their time in exchange for sponsorship benefits, which include your logo on the event t-shirt, event website, sponsorship banner displayed in front of all walkers and spectators, etc. Liver Life Walk features a festival-type atmosphere including activities for kids, food, entertainment and information about the American Liver Foundation. If you or anyone you know is interested in learning more about this opportunity, please reach out to Stefany Arias at sarias@liverfoundation.org or at 646-737-9414. *Please note this is a volunteer opportunity

10030.description: Future Giants is a non profit that has operated in NYC for over 11 years. We specialize in preparing High School students for the social and academic challenges they will encounter after graduation. We have a 100 college acceptance rate and a 99 % on time High School Graduation rate. Last year we created and published a High school book that is being used in several High Schools. We are seeking Volunteers that have a direct or indirect contact with the Mayors of Baltimore and or D.C. It is our hope to recreate our success in those cities as well as open our first multi organization youth center (A.C.E) Future Giants is planning to Launch our Academic + Community = Excellence If you have any contacts with the Mayors of either Baltimore ,MD or D.C ( or the Governor) we would like your assistance in helping thousands of young people achieve their dreams.
10030.title: Reference to Mayor of D.C. and or Baltimore

10030.description: Reading Partners needs volunteers like you to provide students in under-resourced elementary schools in your community with the proven, individualized reading support they need to read at grade level by fourth grade. Reading is the foundation for all future learning.The ability to read transforms lives and can empower children to reach their full potential. Research shows that when students can read at grade level by fourth grade, they have a greater opportunity to succeed in school and in life. With your help, we can equip students with the foundational skills they need to read at grade level. Each week, you will meet one-on-one with your student every week to help them develop strong literacy skills and discover a passion for reading. We'll provide a structured curriculum, in-person training, and ongoing support to help your student thrive. Rigorous research has proven that Reading Partners significantly increases reading proficiency. No teaching experience required and anyone over the age of 14 can volunteer. Flexible Monday to Thursday volunteer times between 9am and 5pm. Visit our website at www.readingpartners.org/volunteer to sign up and learn more.
10030.title: Become a reading partner- make a lifelong impact on a child (PS 123, Manhattan)

10030.description: Reading Partners needs volunteers like you to provide students in under-resourced elementary schools in your community with the proven, individualized reading support they need to read at grade level by fourth grade. Reading is the foundation for all future learning.The ability to read transforms lives and can empower children to reach their full potential. Research shows that when students can read at grade level by fourth grade, they have a greater opportunity to succeed in school and in life. With your help, we can equip students with the foundational skills they need to read at grade level. Each week, you will meet one-on-one with your student every week to help them develop strong literacy skills and discover a passion for reading. We'll provide a structured curriculum, in-person training, and ongoing support to help your student thrive. Rigorous research has proven that Reading Partners significantly increases reading proficiency. No teaching experience required and anyone over the age of 14 can volunteer. Flexible Monday to Thursday volunteer times between 9am and 5pm. Visit our website at www.readingpartners.org/volunteer to sign up and learn more.
10030.title: Become a reading partner- make a lifelong impact on a child (PS 175 Henry Granet, Manhattan)

10032.description: Volunteer with Behind the Book (www.behindthebook.org), a non-profit literacy organization that inspires New York City public school students to explore stories and empower their voices. Through our innovative programs, which are part of the class curricula, accomplished authors visit high-needs pre-K-12 classrooms to guide students in creating their own writing and art projects based on the theme of the author's book. You need no experience or training to volunteer. As a classroom coach, you'll support and encourage students as they work on their projects. This workshop needs your help in Washington Heights, NYC. To volunteer, reply with the program code to volunteer@behindthebook.org. We'll supply the address, directions, and other information when you're confirmed: Program 4PKMW-V Date: Wednesday, April 18th Time: 8:45 - 9:30 AM Volunteer Role: Research Coach About the workshop: With Monica Wellington’s Zinnia’s Flower Garden , pre-kindergartners learned about gardening and planting. They’ll conduct hands-on research about the topic by observing and interacting with live flowers in a \"flower museum.\" Using provided questions and sentence-starters, such as what color is this zinnia?, coaches will guide students in engaging with the display, and record their observations. For dates of other workshops around New York City, please visit http://www.behindthebook.org/current-volunteer-opportunities/ To join our team and receive announcements of new classroom programs and other opportunities as they're scheduled, please complete our brief questionnaire at http://www.behindthebook.org/join-us/volunteer/
10032.title: Research coach for Washington Heights public school literacy program (4mw)

In addition to language classes, we offer a variety of programs such as Citizenship Prep, TASC (high school equivalency), and beginner ESOL conversation. 10019.description: It is difficult and sometimes impossible for seniors to travel by themselves to necessary appointments such as doctors and dentist appointments, and on necessary errands such as food shopping. The Senior Escort program makes these crucial trips possible. Encore’s Senior Escort Program is a volunteer program designed to give much needed assistance and support to aging members of our community. Otherwise, due to physical frailty and disability, vision or hearing impairment, and cognitive problems, our senior neighbors are forced to cancel their trips - which leads to rapid decline in health and quality of life. Things to know: As a volunteer, you will meet the senior at their front door, accompany them to their appointment or errand, and then accompany them back to their home. Trips typically take 1-3 hours, depending on the circumstance. You will travel via public transportation (each individual is responsible for their own metro card) or via cab (the senior participant is responsible for cab fees) The clients we serve live in Manhattan south of 110th Duties include: Helping the older person dress in outerwear such as coat, sweater or hat for the trip Helping the older person lock and unlock his/her residence Helping the older person with physical strains such as assistance on stairs and carrying/pushing the grocery cart Requirements: Commitment of at least 6 months Weekly commitments, preferred Successful criminal background check & reference check Flexible hours Monday-Friday and/or available at least one day a week Attend program orientation & training Must be at least 18 years old Sensitive and empathic with the senior population *Important* Schedule: The program is not a fixed schedule. Requests come in every week, at different times and days Monday-Friday. Volunteers must have flexibility during the work week, i.e. a part-time job, or flexible work hours. It is required that you have at least one entire day free from Monday-Friday, we will place the volunteer on an on-call basis depending on the requests that come in that week. Your role as a volunteer in this program is incredibly valuable and rewarding. Senior program participants are so grateful for your time and help. It is a simple but vital service.
10019.title: URGENT NEED! Encore’s Shop & Escort Program. Accompany Seniors To Medical Appointments. Thank You!

10019.description: Estamos buscando un voluntario para acompañar a un encantador señor de 90+ años. Él vive en la parte sureste de la ciudad de New York. A él le encanta jugar domin ó , mirar noticias y novelas. Él te necesita solo una hora a la semana. GRACIAS. We match isolated and lonely seniors with volunteers in the community who make weekly visits in the senior’s home. The Friendly Visiting program is an opportunity to form rewarding relationships and ongoing companionship for both seniors and volunteers. Seniors and their visitor can converse and enjoy the company, take part in activities like going to cafes and museums, share stories, learn new skills, and a variety of other things based on the desires of the companions. You will be matched with a senior who has a similar personality and interests and you can decide together how to spend your time. Visits can easily fit into your schedule because matches are made based on your availability. We ask for a minimum commitment of 6 months or 1 year. Your time as a friendly visitor is invaluable, and you gain a new friend!
10019.title: Necisitamos Voluntario Para Acompañar Encantador Caballero De 90 Años - Adora Jugar Dominó ¡Gracias!

10018.description: As climate change increases, one of the expected impacts is that temperatures in some areas will increase, and more generally extreme temperatures will become more likely. This is expected to put increased stress on the demand for heating and cooling - an aspect of energy production that has not gained the same traction as the large gains solar and wind have built in recent years. Global Green is a national environmental non-profit with offices in New Orleans, NYC, Los Angeles and NYC. We're seeking help from a researcher to evaluate market conditions, and best available technologies for renewable heating and cooling as a component of climate resiliency. Global Green is seeking 2-3 volunteers with a focus on: - policy and market conditions research - technology assessment and evaluation Each volunteer opportunity can be structured around the skills and interests of each volunteer while fitting within the larger overall research program. Additionally, we welcome research to be published as authored or co-authored content on Global Green's blog.
10018.title: Renewable thermal and Resiliency Research
10018.org: Coalition for Resource Recovery Global Green USA

10018.description: DESCRIPTION The Trevor Project is dedicated to recruiting qualified volunteers to provide life-saving, life-affirming support to lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, queer, and questioning (LGBTQ) youth. Our volunteers accomplish societal and individual change by creating safe spaces for LGBTQ youth in crisis and promoting awareness of Trevor’s resources. Trevor Lifeline volunteers are trained to answer calls on the Trevor Lifeline from young people who are feeling suicidal or need a safe, non-judgmental place to talk. This is an onsite volunteer opportunity and those interested need to live near our call centers which are located in LA. Time Commitment: **Note: Volunteers must be available for all training dates and times. Lifeline LA and NY Updates Spring 2018 Training: Orientation: Thursday, April 12th | 7:00 PM - 9:00 PM PST and EST Training Dates: April 14-15th, 21-22nd (Sat/Sun) | 9:30 AM - 6:30 PM PST and EST Post-Training: Thursday, May 24th | 7:00 PM - 9:00 PM PST and EST Trevor Lifeline Shift Times (we ask that volunteers commit to two 4-hour shifts per month): Sunday - Tuesday | 1:45pm - 6:00pm EST (New York) / 6:30pm - 11:0pm PST (LA) Wednesday - Thursday | 5:45pm - 10:00pm EST (New York) / 10:30am - 3:00pm PST, 6:30pm - 11:00pm PST (LA) Friday - Saturday | 1:45pm - 6:00pm EST (New York) / 2:30pm - 7:00pm PST, 6:30pm - 11:00pm PST (LA) Required Skills and Qualifications: You are open to constantly learning. You are good at practicing self-care. You fit the profile of an ideal Lifeline volunteer: Genuine Empathetic Non-judgmental Empowering HOW TO APPLY **Please note: You must be at least 18 years old to volunteer. If you are under 18, please consider our Trevor Youth Ambassador Council. For more information, visit our website on trevorproject.org or reach out to our Community Engagement Coordinator Ashley Choi at Ashley.Choi@thetrevorproject.org.
10018.title: Trevor Project NY Lifeline Volunteer

TO QUALIFY AS A SEED COACH, YOU ARE: Equipped with at least two years of professional experience and great writing skills Ready to commit to Attendance at Boot Camp Digital once a week bi-weekly one-to-one writing and college sessions (Sept-Nov) Monthly in-person SEED workshops (Sept-Dec), and other special events Prepared to maintain clear and frequent communication with Seeds of Fortune, Inc.’s Program staff and your Scholar Eager to share in our mission to empower the next generation of women of color ​ AS A SEED COACH, YOU CAN EXPECT:​ To become an essential part of a young girl finding her voice Training and ongoing guidance as you build her college application Frequent communication with compassionate and knowledgeable staff and experienced volunteers An opportunity to grow with a dynamic community, and team retreat

10038.description: NYC Take Steps is the Foundation’s largest fundraising event in the nation. Help make our event a success. We’re making some great improvements to our festival, walk and finish areas. Share this special event with us! Nearly 1 in 200 Americans live each day with Crohn's disease or ulcerative colitis, life-changing digestive diseases. Living with these inflammatory bowel diseases (IBD) can be painful and isolating. The Crohn's & Colitis Foundation is dedicated to curing Crohn's and colitis, and to improving the quality of life of children and adults affected by these diseases. The Take Steps community also offers a safe, supportive environment for patients and families. Patients connect with others familiar with the ups and downs of IBD, as well as the friends who support their journey. The Foundation has invested almost $300 million in research to date, enabling groundbreaking treatments and greatly enhancing lives. Make a Difference Today! There are four shifts available: volunteers can take as many opportunities to contribute as they wish. Set-up: 11:00am - 5:00pm Unloading supplies Arrange barricades Decorations Signage Assist vendors Festival: 4:30pm - 9:00pm Festival Kick-off Kid Zone Distribute T-shirts, incentives, food informational materials Usher participants Walk Guide & Spirit Crew: 6:00pm - 8:00pm Event Breakdown: 8:00pm - 10:00pm We cannot make it happen without your help! Please contact us if you have more questions.
10038.title: NYC Take Steps for Crohn’s & Colitis - Thursday May 17, 2018 at Pier 16 at the South Street Seaport
10038.org: Crohn's & Colitis Foundation - Greater NY Chapter

10038.description: Join the American Lung Association as we raise awareness and funds to fight against lung cancer and for lung health. Together, we are a FORCE to be reckoned with. The American Lung Association is recruiting volunteers to help at the upcoming Lung Force Walk on Saturday, May 19, 2018. The event will be at South Street Seaport, Pier 16 New York, NY 10038. You can volunteer anywhere from 7:30 am until approximately 2:30 pm. We are unable to have a successful event without volunteers like you. Please reach out to me if you have any questions or concerns. Did you know? Lung cancer is the #1 cancer killer in America, and most people aren’t aware. Anyone can get it - if you have lungs, you can get lung cancer, and it’s on the rise in women. More than 33 million Americans suffer from asthma, COPD (which includes emphysema and chronic bronchitis), and other lung diseases.
10038.title: NYC Lung Force Walk

10038.description: Food from cafeterias after lunch is usually thrown away. But that clean, unplated lunch food can be served to others. Join us on this hour-long food rescue event from an office cafeteria and deliver this wholesome, high-quality food to the food insecure! This event will end at Here There & EVERYwhere, located at 80 Centre St, New York, NY 10013. Heavyweight: the average amount of the total pounds of food rescued from this event is 60 lbs.
10038.title: Feed the Hungry and Fight Food Waste Fridays 2:30PM!

10038.description: Mentor a 13-18 year old student to provide guidance and broaden his or her horizons. Help a student grow to be confident, caring young adult by becoming a role model and someone he or she can rely on. Mentors and mentees are matched after carefully considering the goals of the mentee and what the mentor can do to support that goal. We are currently looking for more male mentors. The mentoring program is for males and females, but as of now, we do not have enough male mentors.
10038.title: Middle School/High School Mentor (male)

10038.description: Teach 4th and 5th graders the fundamentals of basketball and what teamwork really is. Coach the students and help them win games against other schools by guiding them through the seasons. Be the one to show the young students the love for the game.
10038.title: Volunteer Basketball Coaches Needed

10038.description: Reading Partners needs volunteers like you to provide students in under-resourced elementary schools in your community with the proven, individualized reading support they need to read at grade level by fourth grade. Reading is the foundation for all future learning.The ability to read transforms lives and can empower children to reach their full potential. Research shows that when students can read at grade level by fourth grade, they have a greater opportunity to succeed in school and in life. With your help, we can equip students with the foundational skills they need to read at grade level. Each week, you will meet one-on-one with your student every week to help them develop strong literacy skills and discover a passion for reading. We'll provide a structured curriculum, in-person training, and ongoing support to help your student thrive. Rigorous research has proven that Reading Partners significantly increases reading proficiency. No teaching experience required and anyone over the age of 14 can volunteer. Flexible Monday to Thursday volunteer times between 9am and 5pm. Visit our website at www.readingpartners.org/volunteer to sign up and learn more.
10038.title: Become a reading partner- make a lifelong impact on a child (PS 126 Jacob August Riis, Manhattan)

10013.description: Every summer CMP acts as an official provider for the Summer Youth Employment Program (SYEP), a program that connects youth aged 16-24 to employment opportunities across the city. This summer CMP is expected to assist 700 youth in gaining work experience, developing their financial literacy and exploring future careers. You can learn more about the program here: http://www1.nyc.gov/site/dycd/index.pageThis service opportunity will help summer job-seeking youth in filling out the SYEP Application interviewing them and helping them a select an ideal work site where they can learn and grow. Responsibilities Attend volunteer orientation and learn about the enrollment process. Develop an understanding of assigned participating work sites. Get to know the candidates educational background, career goals and interests. Match candidates to an appropriate work site. Qualifications: Strong communication skills. Organized and can complete enrollment process in a timely manner. Previous experience working with young adults is a plus. Time frame: Tentative Dates: first two weekends of April 4/7, 4/8, 4/14 and 4/15 Time: 9am-5pm Dates and times are flexible based on the volunteer’s availability. Benefits: Free lunch provided on day of enrollment. Opportunity to give back to the community and make professional connections.
10013.title: SYEP Job Interviewer

10013.description: We are having our annual gala on April 12th and need volunteers to help check guests in, collect donations, greet guests, and do other miscellaneous tasks (we have servers, etc.). This is a terrific opportunity for those interested in photography, human rights, diversity, etc!
10013.title: Spring Gala 2018

10013.description: LearningSpring School, a K-8 non-profit school for children on the autism spectrum, is seeking volunteers for its annual LSS Blooms Benefit on Thursday, April 19th. This year we will be honoring Robert Manfred, Commissioner of Baseball, on behalf of Major League Baseball’s commitment to autism awareness. We need volunteers to help during the event. The event shift is 5:30 PM -to 9:30 PM (dinner will be provided). Volunteer tasks (during the event): Help with check-in and raffle sales Watch over the Silent Auction table Assist guests with finding their seats Help facilitate the live Home Run Appeal (i.e. noting guests who have raised paddles to signify a pledge) Bidding For Good tech support Attire: Volunteers should wear black business casual clothing (i.e. woman- a black dress, skirt, or black dress pants with a black blouse or top; man- black dress pants with a collared shirt). Please note: All volunteers must be at least 21 years old. For more information, please contact Cara Flynn (Development Coordinator) at cflynn@learningspring.org. To sign up please contact Cara by Wednesday, April 11th.
10013.title: Spring benefit event volunteers

10013.description: Welcome summer in NYC’s backyard playground! Help support the Park's premiere summer fundraising event involving a BBQ and cocktails, kids entertainment and live music along Hudson River Park’s sparkling waterfront to support the Park’s ongoing free programming for families and children, ensuring a fun and enriching experience for all. Entryway/Greeter Volunteers - Greeting guests, directing attendees toward check-in, and providing basic event information Check-In Volunteers - Greet guests, hand out wristbands to attendees after check-in, ensure all attendees sign waivers, and general guest management Curated Care - Support Curated Care staff as needed Super Soccer Stars - Support Super Soccer Stars staff as needed Bubble Dad - Support Bubble Dad staff as needed Big City Fishing - Support Environment and Education staff as needed Face Painting - Line control, manage waiting guests and ensure organization Stroller Parking - Encourage guests to leave strollers, highlight that volunteers will not be responsible for watching strollers (leave at own discretion) Info Table - Distribute collateral, answer guest questions, and direct partners Perimeter Marshalls - Ensure/direct all guests to use main entrance at check-in, answer basic event questions, and block key entryways
10013.title: Hudson River Park Friends Backyard BBQ

10013.description: For many new immigrants, learning English is a first step to full participation in American society. Help them take that first step by becoming a volunteer teacher in English or Citizenship classes. English classes help students improve their communication skills. Citizenship classes help students prepare for the U.S. citizenship test. Volunteers work in teams to plan lessons and teach the class. This fun and rewarding experience gives you a chance to make a difference in the lives of others. Individuals with an interest in education careers are encouraged to apply. Requirements Must have good communication skills and a strong desire to help and work with new immigrants Prior teaching experience is preferred. Bilingual skills are a plus. We prefer volunteers who can commit to teaching at least two semesters Prospective volunteers must complete application and be interviewed. Volunteer Schedule: 9:30 am-11:30am (Tues or Thurs) 10:30 am-12:30 pm (Tues or Thurs) 1pm to 4pm (Saturday) 6:30pm to 8:30 pm (Mon, Tues or Wed) Spring 2018 - February 27, 2018 to June 7, 2018 Summer 2018 - July 9, 2018 to August 18, 2018 Prospective volunteers must complete application and will be interviewed. Please contact us at cpanyc@cpanyc.org for an application OR apply on-line here: http://bit.ly/volunteerteacherapplication For more information: http://bit.ly/VolunteerToTeachEnglishorCitizenshipClass
10013.title: Teach English or Citizenship Class in Chinatown

10013.description: Help rescue catered lunch leftovers from 2 offices in Greenwich Village! We will deliver the food to NYC Rescue Mission, located at 90 Lafayette St, New York, NY 10013. Mediumweight: the average amount of food rescued from this event is 25-50 pounds.
10013.title: Fight Food Waste in Greenwich on Fridays 3:30PM!

10013.description: VOLUNTEER NEEDED FOR OUR MANHATTAN OFFICE INSIDE OF FEDCAP. DUTIES: --Greet the client --Explain that we take pictures and they have to sign a waiver [(we can cut their heads off on the picture, should they not want to be seen) Not mandatory for receiving services] --Measure assist them in tying a tie (if they do not know how) finding a suit, shirt, slacks, shoes, etc. that fits. (They can try on the clothing in the restroom.) --Arrange for the hemming of pants or the sewing on of buttons with the tailor and set a date for the client to pick up the tailored items. If no alterations are needed, then fold up the items and place in a bag for the client. --Keep records of activities and calls in the log. --Be able to work alone, with minimal supervision or with others We are doing one day a week, for now (date to be discussed), but the time will be 10 AM to 3 PM. This is a great opportunity for anyone wanting to go into law enforcement and who wants to see \"the other side\" after a person comes home, someone that wants to be in the fashion industry, or social services/non-profit sector. You will be networking with everyday people, politicians, individuals from different programs (formerly incarcerated individuals, etc.), City organizations/programs, and pastors. There is a possibility that you will be helping with administrative work and our events as well. You must be neat and presentable. We also will need you to assist in pop-up shops and the occasional donation pick up. Check out what we do to get a better feel for 100 Suits http://www.100suits.org/100-suits-speaks Please be reliable! SERIOUS INQUIRIES ONLY!!!
10013.title: Fashion and Justice Volunteer (Queens)

10013.description: Lenox Hill Neighborhood House, widely recognized as one of New York's premier human services providers, is a 123-year-old settlement house that provides an extensive array of effective and integrated services which significantly improve the lives of 15,000 people in need each year on the East Side of Manhattan. Our Senior Center at East 54th Street and Lexington Avenue is a vibrant program that provides hundreds of older adults with educational, cultural, health and social activities every week. We are seeking instructors for a variety of classes and activities including: Zumba Chair Yoga Mah Jong Line Dancing Conversational Italian Book Discussion Group Digital Photography Instructors lead their respective classes/activities once per week on weekdays. If you have one of the skills above and are interested in sharing your time and knowledge with active and enthusiastic older adults please contact Anthony Snowden, Volunteer Director at asnowden@lenoxhill.org or 212-218-0487.
10013.title: Instructor for Senior Center

10012.description: Rescue catered leftovers from 2 offices in SoHo! This event will end at Bowery Mission, located at 227 Bowery, New York, NY 10002. Medium weight: the average amount of food rescued from this event is 30-50 pounds.
10012.title: Fight Hunger is Soho Fridays 3:30PM!

10012.description: NYU has some delicious catering every other week. We need volunteers to pick up this catering and deliver it to a nearby shelter. Heavy pickup: 15-90 pounds
10012.title: Assist NYU in the Fight Against Food Waste Fridays 3:30PM!

10012.description: Housing Works is powered by a vibrant community of volunteers who lend their time, dedication, and passion to many different roles within our organization. For more information about our mission and programs, visit our website: www.housingworks.org We are looking for one individual to support our volunteer coordinator in volunteer recruitment, management, and training. Be a part of one of Housing Works' biggest fundraising events of the year, Design on a Dime, while improving your administrative skills and supporting our volunteer recruitment efforts! The individual will support the volunteer coordinator by doing the following: Researching and recruiting groups and individuals that may be interested in volunteering at our annual Design on a Dime Basic data entry (Salesforce CRM) Answering emails and calls professionally and promptly Administrative task as needed Committing to about 5-10 hours a week Must be available to provide support the final week of April If interested, please email Ida at volunteer@housingworks.org with \"Data Entry Volunteer\" as subject line. Please include resume as an attachment. You must send an email to be considered; requests via VolunteerMatch will not be accepted. Must be 18 or older.
10012.title: Volunteer Recruitment Opportunity!

10012.description: Housing Works is powered by a vibrant community of volunteers who lend their time, dedication, and passion to many different roles within our organization. For more information about our mission and programs, visit our website: www.housingworks.org Be a part of one of Housing Works' biggest fundraising events of the year, Design on a Dime while improving your administrative skills and gaining customer service experience! Responsibilities and Duties Researching and making outgoing donation and/or cold calls to obtain products for upcoming event Basic data entry (Salesforce CRM) Answering emails and calls professionally and promptly Administrative task as needed Excellent phone and computer skills a plus. If interested, please email Ida at volunteer@housingworks.org with \"Data Entry Volunteer\" as subject line. Please include resume as an attachment.
10012.title: Design on a Dime Data Entry Volunteer

10011.description: The Salvation Army has been meeting the needs of individuals in the New York City area for over 125 years. To meet the ever increasing needs in our communities, The Salvation Army relies on the vast and varied talents of hundreds of volunteers to make our operations run smoothly. Presently, we are seeking a detail-orientated volunteer to help with administrative support and data entry. Please consider joining our team where you will enjoy working in a professional, comfortable work environment at our Administrative Headquarters in the Chelsea section of Manhattan.
10011.title: Admin Support/Data Entry
10011.org: The Salvation Army of Greater New York

10011.description: Housing Works is powered by a vibrant community of volunteers who lend their time, dedication, and passion to many different roles within our non-profit organization.By volunteering, you are directly responsible for providing funding to and advocating for New Yorkers affected by homelessness and HIV/AIDS. Thank you for your interest in volunteering at Design on a Dime 2018. We are thrilled to announce that this is our 14th annual Design on a Dime! Last year’s event was a huge success, raising over $1.2 million for homeless New Yorkers living with and affected by HIV/AIDS. The event featured the industry’s top interior designers who created unique room vignettes using items donated from over 100 furniture designers, artists, brands, and individuals. You can find out more about our event here: http://doadnyc2018.splashthat.com/ Each year, DOD depends on the hard work of hundreds of volunteers, and right now we are looking for folks that are comfortable with heavy lifting to help us load in all the awesome furniture and art to be used to create our beautiful vignettes on Tuesday, April 24th from 10 am to 2 pm. PLEASE NOTE: Although we will be providing dollys, volunteers must be lifting and comfortable working with about 40 to 50 pounds All participating volunteers will receive a brand new Design on a Dime 2018 t-shirt along with a 25% discount card to be used during our Public Sale Days or at one of our Thrift Shops (valid for 30 days). If you are interested in volunteering, or would like to sign up your group to volunteer please email volunteers@housingworks.org.
10011.title: LOOKING FOR VOLUNTEERS TO HELP WITH HEAVY LIFTING!

10011.description: Yamba Malawi is planning our largest fundraiser of the year, Gala for Good, on Tuesday, April 24th at IAC in New York City. Each year, Gala for Good features an open bar and tastings by New York's top restaurants, gathering approximately 500 guests. More than just a cocktail party, this event raises $10 for every $1 spent. We are seeking approximately 15 New York-based volunteers (aged 21+) who will assist with setup and breakdown, registration, and the live auction at the event. Once the program has concluded, you are invited to enjoy the rest of the event as our guest. If you are unavailable for the entire event but would still like to help, there will be a volunteer craft night two weeks prior (date TBD), where we will prepare goodie bags, signage, etc. for the event. Interested individuals should email PoLin So at info@yambamalawi.org. Please include which volunteer opportunity you're in interested in, why you'd like to volunteer with us and, if applicable, what event experience you may have.
10011.title: Event Volunteers (21+) for Nonprofit Gala

10011.description: The Children’s Tumor Foundation is a non-profit organization dedicated to funding critical research that will one day end neurofibromatosis. In addition to benefiting those who live with NF, this research is also shedding new light on several forms of cancer, brain tumors, bone abnormalities, and learning disabilities, ultimately benefiting the broader community. The Children’s Tumor Foundation also supports people living with NF and their families with accurate, current and readily accessible information, and assists in the development of clinical centers to create better access to quality healthcare. We are in need of several committee members to join our team of NF Walk Organizers! The role of the committee member may be: To partner with and support the event chair in planning the event within the community. Help motivate, recruit and retain the participants. Communicate with the event Chair on a regular basis and be proactive in the community promoting the event. Assist with logistics and pre-event planning. Securing donations for a raffle, picnic and fundraising. Recruit and organize event-day volunteers. Assist with event-day activity planning and management and post event wrap up. Join the CTF Volunteer Team and see what a difference one person can make! Event site: https://join.ctf.org/event/2018-nf-walk-nyc/e163860
10011.title: New York Charity Walk Committee Members Needed - NYC

10011.description: GRANT WRITER The Grant Writer is primarily responsible for developing and writing grant proposals to foundations and other grant-making organizations, and will persuasively communicate CSP's mission and programs to potential funders. Reporting to the Executive Director, the Grant Writer will assemble and submit grant requests, establish and maintain personal contact and relationships with foundation contacts, conduct prospect research, and maintain a calendar of submissions and other deadlines. To get a response please send RESUME.
10011.title: Grant Writer

10011.description: Education Program Coordinator - Chelsea Sculpture Park. New York , New York. Basic Requirements: BA or MA in related discipline required (Art Education) Post college professional work experience required Demonstrated experience with art education or other informal art programming and curriculum design Demonstrated knowledge of Microsoft computer programs and excellent presentation skills Job Responsibilities: Coordinate and develop of new partner-institution/organization relationships and curriculum Provide leadership and direction towards the design and implementation of art educational programming and curriculum in compliance with national and state learning objectives, accreditation guidelines, and innovative art methodologies Establish and grow professional relationships with constituents, peers, associations and partner schools To Apply: Please submit your resume with cover letter and references to the contact information listed below. Set against the backdrop of the Hudson River, Chelsea Sculpture Park will offer fine art for the public to experience, up close and outdoors. The park's mission is to provide an aesthetic oasis in the Chelsea Cove section of Hudson River Park located between 22nd and 26th Streets, just steps away from the world-class Chelsea Art District. We are looking for a Education Program Coordinator to assist the founder and executive-director of Chelsea Sculpture Park develop and implement an educational program foccusing on the exhibitions of the sculpture park.
10011.title: Educational Program - Coordinator

10011.description: Chelsea Sculpture Park New York, New York Are you considering a future in arts administration, nonprofit management, fundraising, arts education or a related field? This is a great opportunity to gain experience working at a brand new nonprofit arts organization that is dedicated to building a sculpture park on the banks of the Hudson River Park. Gain invaluable insights and learn fundraising strategies as part of a dynamic Development team. Assist with prospect research, special events, direct mail, and our donor database, as well as pursue special projects. Internship credit may be arranged through your academic program. The ideal candidate will be organized and detail-oriented, and have good computer skills. Those with prospect research experience and graduate students in arts administration and arts education are especially welcome. The hours for this position are flexible within the work week. A modest stipend is available. To Apply: Please be sure to include current contact information so that we may arrange an interview. To get a response please send RESUME .
10011.title: Development Intern

10011.description: The Children’s Tumor Foundation is a non-profit organization dedicated to funding critical research that will one day end neurofibromatosis. In addition to benefiting those who live with NF, this research is also shedding new light on several forms of cancer, brain tumors, bone abnormalities, and learning disabilities, ultimately benefiting the broader community. The Children’s Tumor Foundation also supports people living with NF and their families with accurate, current and readily accessible information, and assists in the development of clinical centers to create better access to quality healthcare. We are in need of an event chair to lead our organizational committee! Position Summary: Serve as the Lead Event Organizer, overseeing the event from beginning to end. Organize/recruit, motivate and lead a committee of other volunteers as they recruit teams, obtain sponsorship, and plan the event details. Roles and Responsibilities Work with Operations Chair and Staff Partner to follow all Children’s Tumor Foundation policies and procedures as well as state laws and local ordinances as well as the program standards. Know and be able to articulate the CTF mission, vision and messaging points. Recruit volunteer committee leads to manage the various aspects of the event (such as: Media & Publicity, Logistics, Operations, Recruitment, Event Volunteers). Work with Staff Partner to schedule committee meeting dates, develop agendas and facilitate committee meetings. Monitor progress of committee chairs through regular communication to ensure tasks are completed. Enforce accountability with committee members for assigned tasks and the overall event goals. Adhere to pre-approved budget through work with Staff Partner. Assist with identification of the appropriate person to succeed you as Chair. Arrange for appropriate recognition of sub-committee members and event day volunteers. Preferred Skills and Experience: Previous fundraising event organization is preferred but not essential. Organizational skills including general organizing, planning, time management, scheduling, coordinating resources and meeting deadlines. Comfort speaking in front of a group or potential sponsor Excellent communication skills Ability or experience overseeing the work of others. Spreadsheet and/or Google Drive knowledge and experience is a plus. Event site: https://join.ctf.org/event/2018-nf-walk-nyc/e163860
10011.title: New York Experienced Event Organizer Wanted -NYC

10011.description: Computer/It - Tech Support - All aspects of tech support for the organization including maintenance, troubleshoot, specially ANTI-VIRUS, and optimal functioning of the system. Must have experience with Microsoft and Windows systems. To get a response please send RESUME .
10011.title: Computer support

10115.description: Set Up: This station is responsible for table set up, signage, and general set up before the race starts. Parking Attendants: This station is responsible for helping direct traffic before the race begins. Green Team: This station helps HFTC with trash and recycling of plastic, cans, etc. Team Village: This station helps the Team Village with set up and break down of tables and signs, and directing team members to their team area. Registration: This station helps us get people registered on race day morning! Packet Pickup: This station applies to packet pickup held prior to the race as well as the morning of. Volunteers will help hand out packets and t-shirts to registered participants. Hospitality: This helps prepare, replenish, and serve the food and beverages we provide at our events. Volunteer Check-In/Info Center: This station makes sure all volunteers know where to go to their stations and provides information regarding each volunteer job. Water Stops: This station is in charge of placing all water, cups, and troughs at the water stops. Course Monitors: This station is responsible for monitoring and making sure the runners stay on course. Finish Line: This station is responsible for assisting the race director with scoring chips and other duties needed at the finish line. Kids Zone: This stations helps with any kid activities we have at the event (face painting, sidewalk chalk, yard games) as well as with the kids run, which takes places once the 5K run/walk is finished. Clean Up: This station is responsible for cleaning up trash, tearing down tables, chairs, and banners. With a lot of hands, clean up can go by really quickly!
10115.title: Head for the Cure 5K - New York

10031.description: The Boys & Girls Club of Harlem’s (BGCHarlem) mission is to provide access and opportunity for youth to reach their full potential as responsible members of the community. We believe that success is within reach of every young person that walks through our doors. Our kids benefit from trained, caring professional staff and volunteers who help them take control of their lives, envision productive futures and reach the goals. Core to this is the development of strong character and leadership skills and we seek your support to both models and encourage them as a volunteer group mentor for our Girls mentoring program. Our Girls mentoring program provides girls ages 8-17, with the skills to develop positive self-esteem, and adopt healthy lifestyle habits. Weekly participants engage in discussions on a range of topics that include media influences on females, dating relationships, and health prevention and education. Volunteers, with the support of BGCHarlem staff, will help to facilitate these discussions over a 10-week session, guiding youth through a curriculum that builds competencies in: Understanding and implementing the Boys and Girls Club of Harlem program Having in-depth and potentially uncomfortable conversations about challenges facing teens today Discussing nutrition, cooking and maintaining a healthy lifestyle. Our Boys Mentoring program uses interactive activities to educate males 8-12 and 13-17 on the critical issues that young men face including decision making, wellness, careers and employment, relationships, and self-esteem This opportunity is on Monday evenings.
10031.title: Boys and Girls Group Mentoring

10031.description: Reading Partners needs volunteers like you to provide students in under-resourced elementary schools in your community with the proven, individualized reading support they need to read at grade level by fourth grade. Reading is the foundation for all future learning.The ability to read transforms lives and can empower children to reach their full potential. Research shows that when students can read at grade level by fourth grade, they have a greater opportunity to succeed in school and in life. With your help, we can equip students with the foundational skills they need to read at grade level. Each week, you will meet one-on-one with your student every week to help them develop strong literacy skills and discover a passion for reading. We'll provide a structured curriculum, in-person training, and ongoing support to help your student thrive. Rigorous research has proven that Reading Partners significantly increases reading proficiency. No teaching experience required and anyone over the age of 14 can volunteer. Flexible Monday to Thursday volunteer times between 9am and 5pm. Visit our website at www.readingpartners.org/volunteer to sign up and learn more.
10031.title: Become a reading partner- make a lifelong impact on a child (PS 192 Jacob H. Schiff, Manhattan)

10016.description: Thanks so much for wanting to make a difference. We are recruiting volunteers to be group facilitators for children ages 5-17 (groups are divided according to age), as well as event and fundraising helpers. Please view below for the volunteer type requirements and descriptions. The family and children group sessions are held at two Manhattan school locations, midtown and harlem. I invite you to visit our website at www.acaringhand.org to learn more about us and to acquire an application: https://docs.wixstatic.com/ugd/ea9db3_572250eb6e1d4899bd0837d204ffdbe9.pdf. Feel free to contact me directly at RobinGoodman@acaringhand.org for more information or to send A Caring Hand application. View our video about our group program directly at https://vimeo.com/90184263 or on our website, acaringhand.org VOLUNTEER TYPES AND REQUIREMENTS 1) GROUP FACILITATORS: Group facilators must complete an application, have an interview, and attend a 8-12 hour training. One year commitment is required to co-facilitate the child and teen groups. 11 wee group session is held 3 times per year, summer, fall and winter ( Sept - June). A monthly drop in session is held Sept-June. Attendance at a 11 week session is a minimum requirement. In certain circumstances, a commitment for the monthly groups can be accommodated. Group facilitators are assigned to weekly groups during the weekdays and evenings. The days when groups are held vary from season to season. Currently groups are held on Tuesdays and Wednesdays, and our monthly groups are held on Thursdays. Indicate your best evening availability during the week. Groups are held at two Manhattan school locations, midtown and Harlem. 2) VOLUNTEER EVENT HELP: We rely on the generous donations from individuals, corporations, and grants to fund our work. We need a strong volunteer event committe to help with all aspects of our annual gala and other fundraising activities. 3) VOLUNTEER HELPER AND FUNDRAISING: We always need extra hand on deck for various short term projects throughout the year. The projects range from stuffing envelopes and answering phones to doing outreach in th community. Certainly if you have a particular skill aor specific time you would like to help out you should let us know. We also rely on volunteers to help with A Caring Hand, The Billy Esposito Foundation fundraising activities and other board projects. WE WELCOME VOLUNTEERS WITH A RANGE OF EXPERIENCE! APPLY TODAY! Follow this direct link: https://docs.wixstatic.com/ugd/ea9db3_572250eb6e1d4899bd0837d204ffdbe9.pdf or visit our website at www.acaringhand.org for an application.

10014.description: The ALS Association Greater New York Chapter needs YOUR help! With the 2018 New York City Walk to Defeat ALS approaching, we hope you will be able to volunteer with us to help make this year’s Walk a success. Almost 190 walkers have raised over $40,000 dollars to date! We need your help on the day of the event to ensure that everyone has a great experience. Because of the energy and support that our volunteers provide on the day, our walkers come back year after year to enjoy the Walk! When: Saturday, May 5 th Where: Hudson River Park at Pier 45 Registration opens at 9:00AM, opening ceremonies are at 10:30AM and the Walk begins at 11:00AM, so we’ll need people to volunteer before and/or during the Walk. You can pick whichever time slot that would work best for you! We can provide up to 6 hours of community service! _________________________________________________________________________ If you are interested, please email vjung@als-ny.org with: 1. Full Name (and those volunteering with you) 2. Walk(s) you would like to volunteer at 3. Cell Phone # 4. What time slot between 8:00AM-1:00PM are you available? (Time slots include 8AM-11AM, 11AM-1PM, 8AM-1PM) 5 . Do you have any physical limitations? 6. Are you (or anyone with you) under 18? *If under 18, we need to have a signed permission slip prior to volunteering _________________________________________________________________________ Positions include**: Registration Food Parking Marshal Walk Marshal Water Station T-Shirts Kids Zone Tribute Banner Cheer Photographer Assistant Early Bird Set-Up **will be chosen based on availability and time commitment If you have any questions or concerns, please contact Vivian Jung at 212-720-3043 _________________________________________________________________________ You can register for the Walks at alswalks.org or call Meg Emery at 212-720-3049 Interested in becoming a local partner? Learn more about our Chapter's Corporate Partnership Opportunities and the impact your company can have right here in our community. Contact Jillian Saperstein 212-720-3052 | jsaperstein@als-ny.org

10014.description: GO Project: Who We Are and What We Do The GO Project shapes the futures of low-income New York City public school children by providing critical academic, social and emotional support starting in the early elementary years. GO provides year-round educational and family support services to children who are performing below grade level and equips them with the confidence and skills needed to succeed at school, at home and in life. GO School Tutoring: How YOU Can Help During the GO School Saturday program, a professional teacher models a lesson, activity, or project to a classroom of students. Volunteer tutors continue to work with small groups of 2-4 students on the lesson, providing individualized attention which allows the students to thrive. Tutor Responsibilities Tutor small group of students in grades 1st-8th who are in need of academic intervention under Head Teacher’s guidance Punctual and consistent attendance; no more than 3 absences permitted per session (Session I: October-December, Session II: January-April) Actively and enthusiastically participate - support instruction and engagement Help prepare, record, and put away classroom materials Ongoing communication with Head Teacher regarding students’ progress and/or concerns, and with the Senior Director of Community Engagement regarding overall volunteer experience Time Commitment Session I: October-December 2017; 9 Saturdays from 9:00AM-12:45PM Session II: January-April 2018; 14 Saturdays from 9:00AM-12:45PM Attend mandatory orientation and training prior to start of session. *You can choose to be a Committed Volunteer to come each Saturday with 3 allowed absences per session, or a Floater Volunteer to come on the Saturdays that you are available. GO School Fall 2017 Session I October 14, 21, 28 November 4, 11, 18 December 2, 9, 16 GO School Spring 2018 Session II January 6, 20, 27 February 3, 10, 24 March 3, 10, 17, 24 April 7, 14, 21 Locations You can choose to tutor our students at one of the following 6 locations: Manhattan Locations Avenues: The World School (1st-5th Grade): 259 10th Avenue, between 25th and 26th Streets Grace Church School (1st-5th Grade): 86 4th Avenue, between 10th and 11th Streets Grace Church High School (6th-8th Grade): 46 Cooper Square, at 6th Street LREI (1st-5th Grade): 272 6th Avenue, at the corner of Bleecker Street St. Luke’s School (1st-3rd Grade): 487 Hudson Street, at Hudson and Christopher Streets Brooklyn Location Berkeley Carroll (1st- 2nd Grade): 701 Carroll Street, between 6th and 7th Avenues Placement is based on a complimentary match between programmatic need and volunteer strengths. We will honor preferences when possible. Qualifications College students, professionals, retirees, and high school students in good academic standing Commitment to and belief in all children’s ability to succeed and thrive Professional work habits Benefits: How Can We Help YOU Personal gratification through enhancing the lives of young learners Ongoing professional development and training opportunities Leadership opportunities for sustained dedication and commitment Being part of a vibrant and diverse volunteer community How to Apply Application Form Cover Letter/Personal Statement explaining why you want to volunteer with GO Project Resume (for volunteers 18 and older)/High school transcript (for high school students) Personal reference Background check (for those 18 and older) If interested, please fill out the online form at: https://goo.gl/forms/iGs9YOzEUsNCujrk2. The online application form can also be found on our website at: http://goprojectnyc.org/get-involved/volunteer. If you have any questions or would like more information about the available volunteer positions, please contact volunteering@goprojectnyc.org or call 212-533-3744 ATTN: Olivia Nunez, Senior Director of Community Engagement.
10014.title: Help a Child Love to Learn on Saturday Mornings!
